pli-tv-pvr13:2.1: Sp 5.361: Tattha diṭṭhaṁ diṭṭhenāti gāthāya ayamattho – ekeneko mātugāmena saddhiṁ ekaṭṭhānato nikkhamanto vā pavisanto vā diṭṭho, so taṁ pārājikena codeti, itaro tassa dassanaṁ anujānāti. Taṁ pana dassanaṁ paṭicca pārājikaṁ na upeti, na paṭijānāti. Evamettha yaṁ tena diṭṭhaṁ, taṁ tassa “diṭṭho mayā”ti iminā diṭṭhavacanena sameti, “The meaning of diṭṭhaṁ diṭṭhena in the verse is this: a monk is seen emerging or entering a place alone with a woman, and one accuses him of an offense entailing expulsion, and the monk admits to what the other has seen. What was seen does not amount to an offense entailing expulsion, and he does not admit to it. So in this case, what was seen by him agrees with his statement, ‘It was seen by me.’”
pli-tv-pvr13:7.14: Sp 5.363: Otiṇṇānotiṇṇaṁ jānitabbanti otiṇṇañca anotiṇṇañca vacanaṁ jānitabbaṁ. Tatrāyaṁ jānanavidhi – ettakā codakassa pubbakathā, ettakā pacchimakathā, ettakā cuditakassa pubbakathā, ettakā pacchimakathāti jānitabbā. Codakassa pamāṇaṁ gaṇhitabbaṁ, cuditakassa pamāṇaṁ gaṇhitabbaṁ, anuvijjakassa pamāṇaṁ gaṇhitabbaṁ, anuvijjako appamattakampi ahāpento “āvuso samannāharitvā ujuṁ katvā āharā”ti vattabbo, saṅghena evaṁ paṭipajjitabbaṁ, “Otiṇṇānotiṇṇaṁ jānitabban: a statement is to be known as otiṇṇa or anotiṇṇa. This is the way of knowing: ‘The accuser should say this first and that afterwards. The accused should say this first and that afterwards.’ This is to be known. The accuser is to be assessed, so is the accused and the investigator. If the investigator mangles (his speech) even a little, he should be told, ‘Reflect, fix it up, and then speak.’ This how the Sangha should proceed.”
pli-tv-pvr13:11.2: Sp 5.364: Na ca nissāya puggalanti “ayaṁ me upajjhāyo vā ācariyo vā”tiādinā nayena chandādīhi gacchanto puggalaṁ nissāya karoti, evaṁ na kareyya, “Not depending on individuals: through the method that begins with thinking, ‘This is my preceptor or teacher,’ one creates dependence on an individual through desire, etc.”
pli-tv-pvr13:13.2: Spk 1.188: Vītiharatīti katassa paṭikāraṁ karoti, “Vītiharati: he acts with a counter-action toward the one who has acted.”
